body.translated_text:
Now, The Thirty Verses on Consciousness-Only
This is the work of Ācārya Vasubandhu.

children.translated_text: The manifold designations of self [<s>ātman</s>] and phenomena [<s>dharma</s>] that occur,

children.text: vijñānapariṇāme 'sau pariṇāmaḥ sa ca tridhā // Tvk_1 //
children.translated_text: they are [transformations] in the transformation of consciousness. This transformation is of three kinds.
[These three are] maturation [<s>vipāka</s>], that called "mentation" [<s>manana</s>], and the consciousness of the object [<s>viṣayavijñapti</s>].
Among them, the consciousness called "receptacle consciousness" [<s>ālayavijñāna</s>] is the maturation [and it is] all-seeded.
It [is endowed] with unconscious grasping, taking up, and placing, and [is]
always associated with contact [<s>sparśa</s>], mental engagement [<s>manaskāra</s>], feeling [<s>vedanā</s>], discernment [<s>saṃjñā</s>], and volition [<s>cetanā</s>].

Its feeling is equanimity [<s>upekṣā</s>], and it is unhindered and indeterminate [<s>anivṛtāvyākṛta</s>]. Similarly, [it is associated with] contact and so forth [<s>manasikāra</s>, <s>saṃjñā</s>, and <s>cetanā</s>].
And it evolves like the stream of a river.
Its cessation occurs in arhatship. Dependent on it, there arises
a consciousness named "mind" [<s>manas</s>], which has that [<s>ālayavijñāna</s>] as its object and has the nature of mentation.
It is always accompanied by four defilements [<s>kleśa</s>], which are [morally] indeterminate but obscuring [<s>nivṛtāvyākṛta</s>]:
[these are] called "view of self" [<s>ātmadṛṣṭi</s>], "delusion about the self" [<s>ātmamoha</s>], "pride of self" [<s>ātmamāna</s>], and "self-love" [<s>ātmasneha</s>].
It does not [occur] in arhatship, nor in the attainment of cessation [<s>nirodhasamāpatti</s>], nor in the supramundane path [<s>lokottaramārga</s>].

children.text: na nirodhasamāpattau mārge lokottare na ca // Tvk_7 //
children.translated_text: nor in the supramundane path [lokottaramārga].
This is the second transformation. The third [pertains] to the sixfold [bases of] sense [objects].
It is the cognition of objects, and is wholesome, unwholesome, or neutral.
It is associated with the universals [<s>sarvatraga</s>], the particularized [<s>viniyata</s>], the wholesome mental factors [<s>kuśalacaitasa</s>],
as well as with defilements [<s>kleśa</s>] and secondary defilements [<s>upakleśa</s>], and with the three [types of] feeling [<s>trivedanā</s>].
The first [the universals] are contact [<s>sparśa</s>] and so on. The particularized are desire [<s>chanda</s>], resolve [<s>adhimokṣa</s>], mindfulness [<s>smṛti</s>],
concentration [<s>samādhi</s>], and discernment [<s>dhī</s>].

The wholesome [factors] are faith [<s>śraddhā</s>], shame [<s>hrī</s>], and fear of blame [<s>apatrapā</s>], the triad of non-greed [<s>alobha</s>] and so forth, energy [<s>vīrya</s>], pliancy [<s>praśrabdhi</s>], heedfulness [<s>apramāda</s>],
and non-harming [<s>ahiṃsā</s>]. [The defilements are] passion [<s>rāga</s>], aversion [<s>pratigha</s>], and delusion [<s>mūḍha</s>].
[These are:] pride [<s>māna</s>], view [<s>dṛṣṭi</s>], and doubt [<s>vicikitsā</s>], and again anger [<s>krodha</s>] and resentment [<s>upanahane</s>],

children.text: mrakṣaḥ pradāśa īrṣyārtha mātsaryaṃ saha māyayā // Tvk_12 //
children.translated_text: [also] hypocrisy [<s>mrakṣaḥ</s>], spite [<s>pradāśa</s>], envy [<s>īrṣyā</s>], avarice [<s>mātsaryaṃ</s>] together with deceit [<s>māyayā</s>],

[and] dishonesty [<s>śāṭhyaṃ</s>], arrogance [<s>madaḥ</s>], non-harming [<s>avihiṃsā</s>], shame [<s>hrī</s>], fear of blame [<s>apatrapā</s>], lethargy [<s>styānaṃ</s>], excitement [<s>uddhavaḥ</s>],

children.text: āśraddhamatha kausīdyaṃ pramādo muṣitā smṛtiḥ // Tvk_13 //
children.translated_text: lack of faith [<s>āśraddhaṃ</s>], then laziness [<s>kausīdyaṃ</s>], negligence [<s>pramādaḥ</s>], loss of mindfulness [<s>muṣitā smṛtiḥ</s>],
distraction [<s>vikṣepo</s>], non-alertness [<s>asaṃprajanyaṃ</s>], and also regret [<s>kaukṛtyaṃ</s>] and drowsiness [<s>middham</s>].
Conceptualization (<s>vitarka</s>) and discursive thought (<s>vicāra</s>), these two are the two afflictions [close to <s>samādhi</s>].
The arising [<s>udbhavaḥ</s>] of the five [<s>pañcānām</s>] from the root consciousness [<s>mūlavijñāne</s>] [is] according to the [respective] conditions [<s>yathāpratyayam</s>].

children.text: vijñānānāṃ saha na vā taraṅgāṇāṃ yathā jale // Tvk_15 //
children.translated_text: The five (perceptual) consciousnesses arise in the fundamental consciousness (<s>ālaya-vijñāna</s>) according to conditions, either simultaneously or not, like waves in water.
The arising of mental consciousness [occurs] always, except in [the state of] non-perception,
in the two attainments, in torpor, in fainting, or in a state without <s>citta</s>.
This transformation of consciousness is imagination, [namely,] that which is imagined.

children.text: tena tannāsti tenedaṃ sarvaṃ vijñaptimātrakam // Tvk_17 //
children.translated_text: This transformation of consciousness is discrimination. That which is discriminated by that [discrimination] does not exist. Therefore, all this is only ideation.
Consciousness is indeed all the seeds. Transformation occurs in such and such a way

children.text: yātyanyonyavaśād yena vikalpaḥ sa sa jāyate // Tvk_18 //
children.translated_text: according to a reciprocal influence, by which such and such a type of discrimination arises.
The residual impressions of actions, along with the residual impressions of a dualistic apprehension,
cause another maturation [of seeds] to occur when the former maturation is exhausted.

children.text: yena yena vikalpena yadyad vastu vikalpyate /
children.translated_text: Whatever object is conceptualized by whatever conceptualization,

children.text: parikalpita evāsau svabhāvo na sa vidyate // Tvk_20 //
children.translated_text: that nature is merely imagined and does not exist.
The dependent nature, however, is conceptualization arising from conditions.

children.text: niṣpannastasya pūrveṇa sadā rahitatā tu yā // Tvk_21 //
children.translated_text: The perfected [nature] is its [the dependent nature's] state of being always separated from the former [constructed nature].

children.text: ata eva sa naivānyo nānanyaḥ paratantrataḥ /
children.translated_text: For this very reason, it is neither different nor non-different from the dependent [nature].

children.text: anityatādivad vācyo nādṛṣṭe 'smin sa dṛśyate // Tvk_22 //
children.translated_text: Therefore, it [the perfected nature] is to be spoken of as neither different nor non-different from the dependent [nature], just like impermanence, etc. When this [dependent nature] is not seen, that [perfected nature] is seen.
[Considering] the three kinds of self-nature [and their corresponding] three kinds of non-self-nature,
the non-self-nature of all phenomena is taught.
The first [self-nature] is without self-nature due to its characteristics.
The second [self-nature] is also without self-nature, as it does not arise by itself [i.e., it is dependently originated]. [And finally,] there is the non-self-nature [of ultimate reality].
That [non-self-nature of ultimate reality] is the ultimate truth of phenomena, and that is also their suchness.
And it [this absence of inherent existence] is the ultimate meaning of phenomena and it is also thusness, because it remains so at all times. It is indeed [this] ideation-only.
As long as consciousness does not abide in ideation-only,
the latent tendencies of the dualistic apprehension do not cease.
"Even if one apprehends that 'all this is merely cognitive representation,'"
if one is still clinging to something before oneself, one is not established in mere that [cognitive representation].
When consciousness (vijñāna) does not apprehend any object (ālambana) at all,
then it is established in mere-consciousness (vijñānamātratva), since in the absence of the apprehended (grāhya), there is no apprehension (agraha) of that apprehended.
[This state] is without mind (<s>acitta</s>) and without apprehension (<s>anupalambha</s>). And that is supramundane knowledge (<s>lokottaraṃ jñāna</s>).
The transformation (<s>parāvṛtti</s>) of the basis (<s>āśraya</s>) [occurs] in two ways: through the abandonment of the two kinds of wrongness (<s>dauṣṭhulya</s>).
That very same [transformed basis] is the undefiled (<s>anāsrava</s>) realm (<s>dhātu</s>), inconceivable (<s>acintya</s>), excellent (<s>kuśala</s>), and immutable (<s>dhruva</s>).
It is blissful (<s>sukha</s>), the body of liberation (<s>vimuktikāya</s>), and it is called the Dharma-body (<s>dharmākhya</s>) of the great sage (<s>mahāmuneḥ</s>) [the Buddha].

body.translated_text: The Thirty Verses on Consciousness-Only (<s>triṃśikāvijñaptikārikāḥ</s>) are completed.
This is the work (<s>kṛti</s>) of Ācārya Vasubandhu.
